newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan dlr slips to 11-month low close for 3rd day.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan dlr slips to 11-month low close for 3rd day.

text.p: The Taiwan dollar slid against the U.S. dollar on Friday, hitting an 11-month closing low for the third straight session amid strong U.S. dollar demand from importers and non-delivery forward trading, dealers said.
The local unit ended at T$27.824 against Thursday's T$27.810 close. The Taiwan dollar has not closed lower since its T$27.892 finish on May 28, 1996.
Turnover through dealers was an active US$258 million.
"Local banks have actively sold U.S. dollars, but greenback demand from importers and non-delivery forward trading conducted through foreign banks is even stronger," said one dealer.
Persistent outflows of foreign funds as they took profits from the stock market were factors behind the Taiwan dollar's steady recent depreciation, including Friday's, dealers said.
Capital outflows triggered by worries over social disorder and ongoing constitutional reforms also had depressed the Taiwan dollar, dealers said.
"Most dealers have agreed that the Taiwan dollar is in a gradual downtrend in the near term," the dealer said.
For Saturday, a T$27.80-27.84 range was seen.
